awd_titl_txt: TRIPODS+X:RES:Collaborative Research: Improving Templated Microstructures via Topological Data Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
The importance of microstructures in Material Science is well  recognized. Their local and global geometry influence the functional  behaviors of the materials being designed in a major way.  Therefore,  methodologies for their controlled manufacturing have always been a  focus of intense research. Now, with continuing advancements in  characterization of materials at higher resolution and faster time  scales there is intensified need for data driven digital simulation  and analysis of structure. This project focuses on leveraging the new  area of topological data analysis in advancing the design of  templated microstructure designs through a collaboration between  material and data scientists at Rutgers University and data  scientists at the TRIPODS center at Ohio State University. Templating  is the ideal topical area for this collaboration because it so  definitively directs shape development during processing and can  benefit greatly from deeper topological and statistical analytics.  The researchers will develop a topology-related synergy between Materials  Science, Computer Science, and Statistics that will enable improved  processing of materials using templating. The geometrical and  topological advances developed in this program are expected to also  be extensible to other areas of materials processing, each of which  has unique shape novelty, alignment effects, or texture development.  The project's work could also benefit a range of similar application fields  such as medical image analysis, computational neuroanatomy,  geographic information systems, and engineering designs. Indeed,  collaborations to apply geometric/topological methods to some of  these other application fields are already underway at the TRIPODS  center at OSU and could benefit from close collaboration with this  Materials-focused program as it develops.

The proposed research involves concepts from mathematical areas  of algebraic topology and geometry, applied statistics, and  computational areas of algorithms and graph theory. These will be  applied to materials microstructures created by templating to help  understand topological interconnections, shapes, and dynamics, which  would be of benefit to functional improvements in device operation.  Research in topological data analysis has brought forth the need to  investigate topological concepts in the presence of finite data,  approximations, and noise, constraints that are always encountered in  real materials characterization. Geometric and topological  computation with intentionally structured materials will yield big  and diverse data that can influence and improve future material and  device fabrication efforts. These new data methods will be of  interest to the topological and statistical communities as well as  open up new avenues for predicting and intentionally creating  structures with enhanced functionality.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

por.por_cntn:
Research supported by this grant has focused on 3D microstructures found in lithium-ion batteries. These batteries charge and discharge through the motion of dissolved lithium ions in liquid that permeates through both the positive and negative electrode materials. Thus, the charging and discharging rate are controlled to a large extent by the starting porosity in the electrodes and the interconnections between pores in the network. Our collaborative work has aimed at using topological analysis of these 3D microstructures to understand how these interconnected networks might be improved. We have developed a new algorithm for processing typical 3D X-Ray data (using computed tomography) that can reproduce the real microstructure more faithfully during image processing. This analytical approach has been applied to microstructures formed with "templating", which is a process for intentionally creating porosity with different size-scales, shapes, and interconnection possibilities.

As shown in the process flowchart image, our algorithm serves as a filter for noisy grayscale images and improves the ability of the segmentation process to identify the locations of different phases in 3D. Our work then extracted interconnected porosity channels that serve as pathways for the migration of lithium ions during battery charging and discharging. Templating approaches can provide much more linear porosity and improve the rate of lithium ion migration.

 


Last Modified: 01/25/2022
Modified by: Dunbar P Birnie

Images (1 of )
  • This example shows image analysis for a templated sample with very distinct phases 1 and 2, which is relatively easily handled by standard algorithms such as the one developed by Otsu more than 40 years ago.
    Dunbar Birnie
    Copyrighted
    Dunbar P Birnie
    Grayscale image stack in 3D (left) and segmented 3D stack (middle) based on the grayscale histogram data shown at right.
  • This example shows image analysis for a lithium battery microstructure with substantial similarity in phases 1 and 2, making it difficult to interpret 3D images of this composite using standard methods.
    Dunbar Birnie
    Copyrighted
    Dunbar P Birnie
    Grayscale image stack in 3D (left) and segmented 3D stack (middle) based on the grayscale histogram data shown at right � for a much more difficult battery microstructure.
  • Process stages: (a) ref. image defined as "ground truth", (b) simulated image w/ random noise, (c) filtered in 2D, (d) filtered in 3D, (e) segmentation without any filtering (very noisy), (f) segmentation in 2D with better image fidelity, (g) segmentation in 3D with good image fidelity.
    Dunbar Birnie
    Copyrighted
    Dunbar P Birnie
    Process flow-chart used for testing filtering and segmentation steps.

Research supported by this grant has focused on 3D microstructures found in lithium-ion batteries. These batteries charge and discharge through the motion of dissolved lithium ions in liquid that permeates through both the positive and negative electrode materials. As shown in the process flowchart image, our algorithm serves as a filter for noisy grayscale images and improves the ability of the segmentation process to identify the locations of different phases in 3D. Our work then extracted interconnected porosity channels that serve as pathways for the migration of lithium ions during battery charging and discharging.
